No accidental releases of chlorine have occurred at this facility in the past five (5) years.  The facility has an emergency response program that has been reviewed and coordinated by the Cumberland County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) in Carlisle.  The operation and response procedures are reviewed and updated on a frequent basis by the Cumberland County LEPC.  The Cumberland County Hazardous Materials (HAZMAT) Response Team is the designated first-responder in the event of a chlorine leak incident.  This HAZMAT team is state certified and undergoes extensive training in dealing with a variety of hazardous material incidents, including chlorine gas leaks.  

Recommendations to improve safety were made following an April 9, 2024 inspection of the disinfection system by the Borough's Consulting Engineer.  These recommendations included routine review, and updating as necessary, of the written emergency standard operating procedures (SOPs), continued implementation of the operator training program, and increased documentation of routine functions related to the performance of this regulated process.

The Borough of Carlisle Sewer Authority owns the Carlisle Region Water Pollution Control Facility (WPCF), which is operated by the Borough of Carlisle.  The facility's service area is composed of five (5) contributing municipalities, including the Borough of Carlisle, Middlesex Township, North Middleton Township, South Middleton Township, and Silver Spring Township.  The WPCF located at 54 North Middlesex Road in Middlesex Township, Cumberland County, is permitted to process up to 7.0 million gallons per day (mgd) of wastewater as an average annual daily flow and discharges to the Conodoguinet Creek under National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System Permit No. PA0026077.  The Water Quality Management Part II Permit No. 219405 issued November 18, 2009 identifies the Maximum Month Design Hydraulic Loading Capacity as 9.45 mgd and the Design Organic Loading Capacity as 27,460 lbs/day. Wastewater treatment processes include grit and coarse screenings removal, primary sedimentation, secondary activated sludge treatment, clarification, filtration, and disinfection.  Solid material removed from this process is stabilized using post lime addition, dewatered, and utilized for agricultural purposes through land application.  The plant is operated 24 hours per day, 365 days per year.

The WPCF includes a disinfection system comprised of a chlorine scale room, which contains three (3) one ton containers of chlorine liquefied under pressure, a chlorinator room containing chlorinators, various safety equipment, and instrumentation consisting of automated chlorine and flow recorders, electrical panels, and a gas detector/alarm unit.  Up to three (3) full one ton containers containing chlorine may be on site simultaneously and housed inside the chlorine building. A storage rack for up to four (4) empty containers is located outside the building.
